content: How can I help you today?

I guess I'm here because my wife pushed me to come. Things at home have been really tense, and I don't know how to fix it. My son is struggling, my marriage feels like it's falling apart, and I just feel completely lost and overwhelmed.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like you're carrying a lot right now, and it must be overwhelming to feel unsure about how to move forward. What stands out most to you about everything that's happening?

I think the biggest thing is my son’s behavior and how out of control it feels. We’ve tried so many things, and nothing seems to help. It feels like everything is slipping—my relationship with my wife, with my daughter—and I don’t even recognize myself anymore.

It sounds like your son’s behavior is taking a big toll on your family and on how you’re feeling about yourself. It seems like you’ve been putting effort into finding solutions, but it’s wearing you down. It must be hard to feel disconnected from yourself and the people you care about most. What do you think would make the biggest difference for you right now?

I honestly don’t know. I guess I just want to feel some sense of control again, or at least feel like there’s hope that things will get better. Right now, it just feels like I’m failing at everything—being a dad, a husband, even taking care of myself. I don’t know where to start.

It sounds like you're really yearning for a sense of control and hope, but feeling stuck and unsure where to begin. It's clear how deeply you care about your family and yourself, even through this overwhelming time. What do you think it might look like to take even one small step forward—for yourself or your family?
I'm not sure where to start, honestly. Maybe talking through everything here is that first small step? It's hard when it feels like there's no clear solution, but I guess I have to start somewhere.

Starting here—taking this moment to talk things through—is already a step forward. You're showing care for yourself and your family by being here, even in the midst of feeling uncertain. What do you think you'd want to focus on most while unpacking everything?

I think I’d want to focus on figuring out how to help my son first. If we could get him to a better place, maybe things at home wouldn’t be so tense. Then maybe I could figure out how to reconnect with my wife and feel like myself again.

It’s clear how much you care about your son and the well-being of your family. Focusing on him seems like a meaningful place to start, especially since it feels central to so much of what’s happening at home. What kinds of things have you tried so far to support him?

We’ve tried talking to him, setting boundaries, and even changing the way we discipline him, but nothing seems to work. He's angry a lot, and it feels like he’s shutting us out. We’re at a loss for how to reach him.

It sounds like you've really put effort into adjusting how you communicate and respond to him, but it hasn't brought the connection or relief you were hoping for. It must be so difficult to see him pulling away and feel unsure how to break through the anger and distance. What do you think he might need most from you right now, or what’s helped even a little in the past?

Honestly, I’m not sure what he needs right now or what would actually help. I feel like nothing we’ve tried has made a real difference, and that’s so frustrating. I just wish I could get through to him and understand what’s really going on.

Not knowing what he needs or how to reach him sounds frustrating and heartbreaking, especially when you’re doing your best to connect. It’s clear how much you want to understand him and help. What do you think might make it easier for your son to open up, or even for you to feel closer to where he’s coming from?

Not knowing what he needs or how to reach him sounds frustrating and heartbreaking, especially when you’re doing your best to connect. It’s clear how much you want to understand him and help. Have you noticed anything that seems to trigger his anger or moments where he’s more open to sharing?

Triggers for his anger might be related to moments where he feels misunderstood or pressured, but it's hard to pinpoint exactly what sets him off. When he's open, it's usually during quiet moments or when he feels safe, but those times are rare. I just don’t know how to make those moments happen more often.

It’s good to recognize those quiet moments when he feels safe—that’s a start. Maybe focusing on creating more of those spaces where he feels less pressure could help him open up over time. Are there any specific activities or times when you've noticed him feeling more at ease, even if just briefly?

Well, he seems a little more relaxed when we’re outside, like when we go for walks or play catch in the yard. Those moments don’t happen often, but when they do, he’s not as guarded. Maybe it’s something about being active or being out of the house that makes it easier for him to let his guard down.

That sounds like a really positive observation. Those shared activities might be a way to help build some connection with him. Maybe spending more time outside together, even just in small ways, could create more chances for him to open up. How would you feel about trying to do more of those kinds of things regularly?

I think it could be worth a try. It’s one of the few things that seems to work, even just a little. I guess I’d have to make a point to carve out time for it, even when things feel chaotic at home. Hopefully, it could help him feel more comfortable and maybe help me feel like I’m doing something right for him.
